segments.text: He probably never even heard of radar.
He had never heard of radar.
And this was just like a voice from above.
May have made a religious man out of him.
But I think this is what we're beginning to see now a little bit in oceanography.
So many of the things that would have been not possible
20 or 30 years ago, are now becoming commonplace.
If you had some advice you would like to offer a young person, what in oceanography or what particular aspect of oceanography would you suggest to that person that he or she do?
Well, I haven't advised students for a few years now.
Formerly, when a student came down to talk to me about entering oceanography, I would try to see what his goals in life were, and how long he expected to go, and so on.
And I told him that in oceanography, just from the prerequisites we had, that he would get a very broad basic training in the sciences, and that this was essential.
Then he could later go on his way.
If he wanted to make money and get through quickly,

why I told him that you'd never make much money in oceanography, that something like that, why you would be better to shift to some other discipline and stay in a particular discipline, and you would be on the production line at an earlier date.
But if you wanted to

to continue in a very interesting field that had many ramifications outside of your own particular area of interest, you would always find that you had so much more to do than you could possibly do that it would be very satisfying.
And as a result, we've had

people go through and quite a few of them have shifted over to medicine of all things after they've taken some oceanography because we require this chemistry and the other sciences which gave them a good background.
And so I've always maintained that

the first step was to get a good, broad, basic education so you could be acquainted with the different facets, able to do a lot of things, and then to specialize in something that was of particular interest to you.
We lost some students that way.
But I think the ones we retained were probably never felt that they were shortchanged.
And it's surprising to watch what some of the people did go into after they had had their training in oceanography.
Well, Washington has what amounts to, or Washington had what amounted to, the only undergraduate school of oceanography in the country, and certainly had the first.
That's right.
Were there any sort of deliberate plans or ideas you had in terms of the creation of the school?
Did you have some sort of a broad concept of what you thought an oceanographer should be?
Well, we've often felt that an oceanographer should have.
a broad training in the physical and the biological sciences and the math base.
And of course, these were hard to become harder to fulfill as we become more sophisticated in all of the contributing disciplines.
One example, at Friday Harbor, there was a course given that Dr. Thompson called Omnology, which bracketed the field.
And so in this particular course, there would be people from the biological sciences, Bob Miller, for example,

that was director of the California Academy of Sciences for many years, Steinhardt Aquarium, that was here, and Utterback in physics, Thompson in chemistry, and other zoologists, botanists and zoologists, contributed to this course to sort of give people a broad understanding of the general area.
and not to force people in any particular direction, but to open their eyes on the spectrum in which they can look and make up their own minds.
In that way, if they choose unwisely, it's more or less their own doing.
But if they choose unwisely without having some sort of a concept of what other alternatives there are,
then I think that's part of the blame of the instructional staff.
Now, I have now sort of a couple of questions I'd like to ask concerning what amounts to the period between about 1939 and about 1945, 1946.
In the Hydrographic Office,
and on the Bikini Test and in sort of the early work in the Arctic.
Did you notice much conflict between military and civilian personnel in terms of approaches to oceanography or personality clashes either at the Test or in the Hydrographic Office or what have you?
Well, I've had a little bit of experience on both sides.
And personally, I've always gotten along very well with both the civilian and military.
But whenever you get these different groups together, they've, as a rule, been brought up through different things.
pathways of training and so on.
They each have their own job.
So you expect, at times, a little bit of friction.
One of them is based on action and directing other people a great deal.
And the other is based on the science of the situation, what we know for sure, what's imagination.
And that sort of thing.

There have been, and I've worked on a lot of different ships with a lot of different people, and it comes down, I think, not so much as to the difference between a civilian scientist and a particular naval officer.
as far as their different routines are concerned, but goes back to the individuals, the people that can see both sides of a question and leave a flexibility.
There are certain situations where the first thing you must do is save the ship.
It takes precedence over all else.
There are other times when...
you must accomplish your scientific protection or the mission is a failure.
And it goes back to the personalities.
So some cruises are highly successful.
Other cruises may work out not too satisfactorily.
in terms of the beginning, you know, the bringing in of the ships and the vessels, and research time, really, is what I'm thinking of.

There was a time when you first began, in terms of oceanography, where there were just sort of blanket grants, and this is also sort of a follow-up on military and civilian conflicts, possibly, sort of blanket grants given to an institution, and the institution sort of dispersed the grants and
and allowed one to work on his project.

And then later on it seems to me that oceanography became more mission oriented and in one sense and in the other sense in terms of giving grants you had to apply individually for grants and the grants were awarded based upon the individual project.
Now
Which way did you prefer it?
Did you prefer it where the institution just sort of received the grant and then divide the money up in faculty?
Or did you prefer it after NSF came along and you applied for individual grants?
Well, both methods have their advantages and drawbacks.
I think if you're starting up, Bob,

something that I really believe that the early formulation of the Office of Naval Research, which I was pretty well acquainted with as it grew back in Washington, D.C., and the early years where they gave money to the institutions, I think that
was a remarkable system.
I think the Office of National Research has done a very good job over the years.
And some of that same group, of course, went over to the National Science Foundation.
I was at one time in my career involved a little bit in going back and looking over the programs as part of the
group that were advising on oceanography, the executive office of the president, and trying to pass out things.
But I think you have to have a little bit of both, really.
Because, well, of course, there's an awful lot of time lost now
in what I call overhead, which not only as far as the funds are concerned, but I'm thinking of scientist time.
You mean in grant writing and proposal writing?
In grant writing, proposal writing, and so on.
And this will work in different ways.
If you have a benign godfather that looks out after all your interests and takes care of this for you and gives you then full freedom and the funds to go ahead with, that's beautiful.
But there's always a day of reckoning.
And it goes back to the individual, and it goes back to cooperation all along the line.
Between the individual scientists and the administration in his own particular department or so on, and then in the university, it must be framed within the university administration as well.
So it takes a lot of give and take all along the line.
And the better knowledge the different levels have and the understanding, they can do a very good job of administering sometimes if they don't know too much of the details.
But when the chips are really down,
to be sure that you're getting a high percentage of efficiency, why it takes the people in their different ranks to know an awful lot about what goes on at all levels.

And I think this is probably one of the problems in government today, that it's become so complex that you just don't have this direct contact, this chain of knowledge that goes through from the beginning raw materials, you might say, to the finished product.
In the organization of the early O&R office, I assume the idea must have come from Roger Revelle.
Is that correct?
Well, Roger Revelle was over in the Bureau of Ships and was in a very strategic position there.
He was responsible here in a major sense for the scientific operations in the
In 46 that I mentioned.
Yeah.
And so, but there were others that also involved a great deal in that.
Now, Roger was back on the scene.
And from the strict oceanographic standpoint, he was sort of the champion along that particular.
But we had a number of people that were very knowledgeable.
And for a while, the Navy had the Research and Development Board, you see.
And we had some good heads there that were quite cognizant of
what was really necessary to get something going in oceanography.
Before that, we had had, of course, the Rockefeller Fund in the 30s, which built the building at Scripps, Woods Hole, and this building here.
I didn't know anyone built this building, too.
Yes.
This is the Rockefeller Fund building.
And I think from that sort of a stimulus, getting some of the early places going in Hawaii, and then the next big step, I would say, was the Office of Naval Research, which really got things going.
in a more modern sense in oceanography.
There had been an awful lot of the people involved in this that were very much connected with the operations during World War II.
And so they had a good grasp.
A lot of them were civilians at all times.
But there were also some of the Navy people that were quite
cognizant of what was going on.

Were you unhappy when, that's the wrong choice of word, were you surprised rather and somewhat chagrined when the ONR swings away from really research and development and into mission-oriented work almost exclusively?
I think that you have to have a mix in this.
I would say that if you're exclusively mission-oriented, what hurt you is maybe not what you do, but what you're not aware of or don't do.
that you have to have this broad freedom of free inquiry to set the base for the future.
When the chips are down, you don't have much chance or time to find out the basic information you need to carry out your operations.
then you've got to take what you've got at that time.
And it becomes mostly inoperational.
But in the easy times in the world, if there are such things, that's the time that people should take time to learn as much as they can about the environment and how things go.
and to push some of, many will be dead ends, but to push some of this information to its ultimate end, whatever that may be.
Now, excuse me.
I've got something in my throat about the last five minutes.
I must have a sign.
Scripts?
No.
Uh...
As I recall, I met Ravel when I was up in Alaska on one of the cruises.
Oh, okay, because he took a cruise.

He told me he had met you, and he had intimated with sometimes in the 30s, and then when I was listening to the tape, I couldn't figure out when it was because I couldn't put you two together anyplace, you see, because you just say your assignments, woods, holes.
and, you know, and the University of Washington.
So I never really got you somehow in the, when I was looking you up, I never really somehow got you into the Navy.
You know, it didn't make any sense to me.
I was actually in the Coast Guard.
Called me in the Coast Guard.
Yeah, but I worked with the Navy.
And I was in a very unique and satisfying position.
And so I couldn't forget when you first encountered Revell, because when they were putting those groups of people to sit together, you know, up to the bikini test,
I can understand why certain were selected.
And I can understand how you got there from Woods Hole, but I never put you in the service to get you there.
That was the confusing part.
I put Revell in the service, of course.
Yeah.
He was already there.
Excuse me.
It can't be Washington weather, believe me.
The other...
During this period, you're talking about here in the 1940s now, there were three people who sort of dominated the concept of grant giving and oceanography, and the direction oceanography was taking.
And this is an oversimplification, of course, but it's Revell, Columbus Island, of course, and Maurice Ewing.
Yes, and I worked with New Columbus very well.
The first year I was at Atwoods Hall,
why I think there were 13 of us in the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution that were more or less permanent residents during the wintertime.
Floyd So and myself and Columbus Island would run the risk back and forth across Martha's Vineyard.
Dean Bumpus was there.
Morris Ewing was there with Warzel and Albine, and the Whale Man from Harvard, Bilgeville, a part of the time.
And Cywell was there at that time.
And so it was a rather small, fairly close-knit group in some ways.
And that was the time when I became acquainted with a number of people, early people.
Norris Raikstra would come down on weekends.
Big load.
He was pretty well entranced at Harvard by that time, and hardly ever.
ever got down, but we did.
Mary Sears was there, certainly on weekends until she finally built her house down in Woods Hole and stayed down there.
But I think, and I'm just trying to recall just exactly when it was that I met Revell.
And it was, I don't know whether it was
I just can't place it in 1933 or 1934 that he was up in Alaska and had met him then.
And Dick Fleming, I met
I don't know what he calls it or not, when he was up here with Moberg, I think, one time when we had a either Pacific Science Convention here in Seattle or something like that.
And Tommy Thompson, you see, worked with the people at Scripps.
He worked with McKeown.
in 1929, in the Gulf of Alaska, on the currents, and Van Cleve was one of our, that was out on the cruise there.
So it was this time, about that time that I met him.
What sort of man was Columbus Islip?
I had a great admiration for Columbus.
He was rather shy, very open-minded, I think, very concerned with pushing forward
Oceanography, as a scientist, of course, they were pretty well healed.
And you brought the Atlantis I back to Europe and made some cruises up on the Grand Banks, up in Labrador, I think, fairly early on.
And I always recall him saying that this is about the end of just the venture beginning to straighten out.
And one of his big worries here, he says, no, the money is getting fairly tight.
And I'm just worried about laying up the Atlantis one.
And
But he says, I think we got enough information in our data bank that we can weather out two or three years without going to see if we have to.
Well, you know, the story was old since then.
And the man that was really one of the, well, a spill house was occasionally down in Woods Hole, but he was just sort of a weekend visitor at that time.
But Morris Ewing was always a go-getter as far as getting an awful lot done and being a good scientist.
And he had a good little group.
going early on at Woods Hole, working on different projects, his underwater acoustics and so on.
His services were great.
I'll never forget one time he called up, he got stranded up in Middlebury or something like that, up in mid-state, up in Massachusetts.

the communications were terrible in those days he got got called up the oceanographic institution i happened to be the only one around that evening and so i finally he got through he says well i'm i'm up here with all my gear and i need to need transportation and when can you be up and pick me up and i'd never
I don't think I'd...
I don't know whether I'd met him then or not.
Of course, I knew he...
Yes, I had.
I'd met him before because he'd been out of university here one time along the early 30s, just a trip through.
And I said, well, I'll be up and pick you up just as soon as I can get up there.
And to be standing out someplace where I can see you, I just got there.
So I went up and...
and he saw me drive up and he says, my gosh, he said, I thought I was talking to Al Vine.
There are communications with that poor on those old Woods Hole phones.
He never forgot that.
He reminded me of it the last time I saw him here a few years back.
But I had a great appreciation for him.
And it's very unfortunate in my area of the world to bring one of the small ships back from Greenland.
And we gave him a choice of going out the outside, which we always recommended.
But he wanted to get back, take the shortcut,
time a little bit through the Gulf of St. Lawrence, through the Strait of Belle Isle, and his ship was lost with all hands from icing conditions in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.
That was Lafarge, Mrs. Island's brother.
So that was a blow to me and to Columbus, I know.
